title: 108_hr1022
content: The Act may be cited as the "Urban and Rural Disease Prevention and Health Promotion Act of 2003". Congressional findings are also included. The Congress finds that in 1999, 61 percent of adults in the United States were overweight or obese, with all age, racial, and ethnic groups affected. Approximately 300,000 deaths are associated with obesity each year, along with various health conditions. The economic cost of obesity in the US was $117 billion in 2000. It is recommended that American adults accumulate at least 30 minutes of moderate physical activity daily, while children should aim for 60 minutes. Physical activity is crucial for preventing weight gain, losing weight, and maintaining weight loss. However, only a small percentage of American adults meet the recommended levels of physical activity. Lack of leisure-time physical activity is prevalent, with 40 percent of adults in the US not participating. Engaging in physical activity, combined with healthy eating, is effective in managing weight. The use of public recreational facilities and services is directly related to the level of physical activity in individuals and communities. Research shows a positive link between active recreation and disease prevention, promoting general wellness. Grant and loan program established for indoor disease prevention and health promotion centers. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may provide grants and loans for indoor centers for disease prevention and health promotion, which are indoor recreational facilities offering services for disease prevention and health promotion. The eligible entity receiving the grant or loan must own or control the facility, provide services to residents free of charge or at a minimal fee, and adhere to legally binding commitments for 25 years. The Secretary may waive these commitments under certain circumstances. The Secretary may waive commitments if environmental conditions reduce public value or access to the facility, or if the facility deteriorates and an agreement is made for a replacement facility. Grants and loans under this Act may be provided to specific entities such as local governments, state agencies managing public parks, and agencies supporting capital investments for public recreation. Eligible uses of assistance are outlined in the Act. Eligible uses of assistance under this Act include developing indoor centers for disease prevention and health promotion, covering activities like planning, design, construction, site assessment, landscaping, and infrastructure enhancement. Grants and loans can be provided to entities like local governments and state agencies managing public parks. The Secretary may not provide grants or loans to eligible entities that have received funding in the past three fiscal years. Loans under this Act do not accrue interest and have a maximum term of 10 years. Repaid loan amounts are available for additional loans. The Secretary will establish application procedures for grants and loans. The Secretary will establish criteria for selecting eligible entities for grants and loans under the Act based on community need for indoor disease prevention and health promotion centers. A panel of experts will review applications and make recommendations for selection. The Secretary will select eligible entities for grants and loans based on established criteria and recommendations from a panel of experts. SEC. 7 of the Act allocates funds for indoor disease prevention and health promotion centers based on population size of local governments. 50% of the funds are for populations of 50,000 or less, and 50% for populations over 50,000. Additionally, not more than 10% of the funds are allocated for loans. SEC. 8 outlines the requirement for matching funds. SEC. 8 of the Act requires eligible entities to contribute from non-Federal sources for activities under section 5. The contribution can include donated material, building leases, and administrative costs. Any contract for activities at an indoor center for disease prevention and health promotion funded under this Act must ensure that architects, engineers, technicians, laborers, and mechanics are paid wages determined by the Secretary of Labor. The development center must ensure that all laborers and mechanics are paid wages determined by the Secretary of Labor. Eligible entities must certify compliance with this requirement before making any payments under the contract. The provision does not apply to volunteers who receive no compensation or are paid only expenses, benefits, or a nominal fee for their services. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "eligible entity" as an entity eligible for grants or loans, "Secretary" as the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and "unit of general local government" as a political subdivision of a State. SEC. 11. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of Appropriations: The Secretary is authorized to appropriate funds for grants and loans under this Act for fiscal years 2004 to 2008. Regulations may be issued by the Secretary to implement this Act.
